OCR’s Role
OCR’s Role

• OCR determines whether each district “will meet” its MSAP assurances of non-discrimination. The MSAP statute specifies that this determination must be made by the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights. In reviewing "voluntary" plans, OCR, on behalf of the Secretary, determines whether a district's voluntary MSAP plan -- and the district's implementation of that plan -- is "adequate under" Title VI.
• OCR determines whether each district “will meet” its • O C R

In reviewing "voluntary" plans, OCR, on behalf of the
Secretary, determines whether a district's voluntary
MSAP plan -- and the district's implementation of that
plan -- is "adequate under" Title VI.

• OCR conducts annual reviews during the three-year

For All Districts
For All Districts

Relevant Regulations:
Relevant Regulations:

LEAs will provide assurances that they will not engage in discrimination based upon race, religion, color, national origin, sex or disability in employment, assignment of students to schools and courses of instruction, and designing or operating extracurricular activities.
LEAs will provide assurances that they will not engage in
discrimination based upon race, religion, color, national
origin, sex or disability in employment, assignment of
students to schools and courses of instruction, and designing
or operating extracurricular activities.

OCR can ask LEAs for “any information that is necessary for the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights to determine whether the assurances . . . will be met.”
OCR can ask LEAs for “any information that is necessary for
the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights to determine whether
the assurances . . . will be met.”

LEAs Implementing “Required” Plans
LEAs Implementing “Required”
Plans

Relevant Regulation
Relevant Regulation

One way an LEA satisfies the eligibility requirements is if it is “implementing a plan undertaken pursuant to a final order of the court of the United States, or a court of any State, or any other State agency or official of competent jurisdiction, and the order requires the desegregation of minority group segregated children or faculty in the elementary and secondary schools of that agency or those agencies.”
One way an LEA satisfies the eligibility requirements is
if it is “implementing a plan undertaken pursuant to a
final order of the court of the United States, or a court of
any State, or any other State agency or official of
competent jurisdiction, and the order requires the
desegregation of minority group segregated children or
faculty in the elementary and secondary schools of that
agency or those agencies.”

LEAs Implementing “Required” Plans (con’t)
LEAs Implementing “Required”
Plans (con’t)

If you believe that your LEA is under a desegregation requirement, please provide OCR with all relevant documents (court order, copy of relevant State statute, State agency order, etc.).
If you believe that your LEA is under a desegregation
requirement, please provide OCR with all relevant
documents (court order, copy of relevant State statute,
State agency order, etc.).

If the magnet schools component proposed in the project is not specified in the required plan, the LEA is required to obtain approval of the modifications from the court or other agency requiring the plan and submit such approval to OII by June 2, 2010.
If the magnet schools component proposed in the project is
not specified in the required plan, the LEA is required to
obtain approval of the modifications from the court or
other agency requiring the plan and submit such approval
to OII by June 2, 2010.

LEAs Implementing “Required” Plans (con’t)
LEAs Implementing “Required”
Plans (con’t)

If it is anticipated that the LEA will be released from its desegregation obligations (e.g., a court granting unitary status) in the near future, please provide a description of the status of the court proceedings, and the approximate date at which a unitary status decree might be expected.
If it is anticipated that the LEA will be released from its
desegregation obligations (e.g., a court granting unitary
status) in the near future, please provide a description of
the status of the court proceedings, and the approximate
date at which a unitary status decree might be expected.

LEA ineligible.
LEA ineligible.

LEAs Implementing “Voluntary” Plans
LEAs Implementing “Voluntary”
Plans

Relevant Regulations:
Relevant Regulations:

The other way an LEA becomes eligible is if it provides a voluntary plan demonstrating that the plan “ will reduce, eliminate or prevent minority group isolation…either in the magnet school or in a feeder school.”
The other way an LEA becomes eligible is if it provides
a voluntary plan demonstrating that the plan “ will
reduce, eliminate or prevent minority group
isolation…either in the magnet school or in a feeder
school.”

Voluntary plans must be “adequate under” Title VI.
Voluntary plans must be “adequate under” Title VI.

Common Problems OCR Encounters In MSAP Reviews
Common Problems OCR
Encounters In MSAP Reviews

• The contact person listed on the application is not available during the Summer, which is when OCR will be calling – if necessary – to discuss the application or to request additional information.

MSAP requirements or about unique situations in your district which may raise questions about the MSAP non-discrimination assurances, you may contact OCR staff attorney Christine Bischoff at christine.bischoff@ed.gov.
